doc_names: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

event.doc_name: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: Petitioners-Plaintiffs (“Petitioners”) are Venezuelan men in immigration custody at risk of imminent removal under the President’s Proclamation—signed in secret on March 14, 2025, and published the next day—invoking the Alien Enemies Act (“AEA”), a wartime measure that has been used only three times in our Nation’s history: the War of 1812, World War I and World War II.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Petitioners are Venezuelan men in immigration custody at risk of imminent removal under President’s Proclamation signed March 14, 2025, published March 15, 2025, invoking the Alien Enemies Act

evidence.text: The Proclamation, Invocation of the Alien Enemies Act Regarding the Invasion of the United States by Tren de Aragua (Mar. 15, 2025), authorizes “immediate” removal of noncitizens that the Proclamation deems to be alien enemies, without notice or any opportunity for judicial review.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Proclamation authorizes immediate removal of noncitizens designated as alien enemies without notice or judicial review

evidence.text: The Proclamation, Invocation of the Alien Enemies Act Regarding the Invasion of the United States by Tren de Aragua (Mar. 15, 2025), authorizes “immediate” removal of noncitizens that the Proclamation deems to be alien enemies, without notice or any opportunity for judicial review. It also contorts the plain language of the AEA by claiming that the Venezuelan criminal gang Tren de Aragua (“TdA”) constitutes a foreign government for purposes of the AEA and is engaged in an invasion or predatory incursion against the United States.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Proclamation designates Venezuelan citizens as alien enemies by labeling the gang Tren de Aragua as a foreign government

evidence.text: Pursuant to the Proclamation, on March 15, the government deported at least 137 noncitizens to a brutal prison in El Salvador, without any review of any aspect of the determination that they are alien enemies.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: At least 137 noncitizens were deported to a brutal prison in El Salvador without review on March 15, 2025

evidence.text: Petitioner D.B.U. is a thirty‑two‑year‑old Venezuelan national who is detained at the Denver Contract Detention Facility, and who, having been erroneously alleged to be a member of Tren de Aragua, is at imminent risk of removal under the Proclamation.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Petitioner D.B.U. is a 32‑year‑old Venezuelan national detained at the Denver Contract Detention Facility and faces removal under the Proclamation

evidence.text: On January 26, 2025, D.B.U. was apprehended at a party he had been invited to by friends who were not Venezuelan. ICE and the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) raided the party, and subsequently both agencies have repeatedly characterized it as a “Tren de Aragua party” in public communications.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: D.B.U. was apprehended on January 26, 2025 at a party raided by ICE and DEA and is alleged to be linked to Tren de Aragua

evidence.text: Petitioner R.M.M. is a twenty‑five‑year‑old Venezuelan national who is detained at the Denver Contract Detention Facility, and who, having been labeled by ICE as a “known member” of Tren de Aragua, is at imminent risk of removal under the Proclamation.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Petitioner R.M.M. is a 25‑year‑old Venezuelan national detained at the Denver Contract Detention Facility and faces removal under the Proclamation

evidence.text: On March 1, 2025, he was arrested and detained at the Denver Contract Detention Facility. On April 11, 2025, ICE filed a heavily redacted Form I‑213 into R.M.M.’s bond case stating that “Subject has been identified as a Associate/Active of Tren de Aragua,” that R.M.M. was “believed to be an associate of TdA,” and that R.M.M. was a “known member of the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua.”
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: R.M.M. was arrested on March 1, 2025, detained at Denver Contract Detention Facility, and ICE filed a Form I‑213 alleging his association with Tren de Aragua

evidence.text: The proposed class satisfies the requirements of Rule 23(a)(1)... The proposed class includes numerous future noncitizens who will be subjected to the Proclamation.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The proposed class includes all noncitizens in custody in the District of Colorado who were, are, or will be subject to the March 2025 Proclamation

evidence.text: This case arises under the Alien Enemies Act (“AEA”), 50 U.S.C. §§ 21‑24; the Immigration and Nationality Act (“INA”), 8 U.S.C. § 1101, et seq.; the Convention Against Torture (“CAT”), see Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998 (“FARRA”), Pub. L. No. 105‑277, div. G, Title XXII, § 2242, 112 Stat. 2681, 2681‑822 (1998) (codified as Note to 8 U.S.C. § 1231); the All Writs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1651; and the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The case arises under the Alien Enemies Act (50 U.S.C. §§ 21‑24), the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. § 1101, et seq.), the Convention Against Torture (8 U.S.C. § 1231), the All Writs Act (28 U.S.C. § 1651), and the Fifth Amendment

evidence.text: D.B.U. has a single tattoo of his niece’s name.

evidence.text: D.B.U. is not a member of and vehemently denies any connection to Tren de Aragua.

add_extracted.value: D.B.U. denies membership in and is not a member of Tren de Aragua.

evidence.text: D.B.U. has been physically attacked based on his protests against the Venezuelan government.

add_extracted.value: D.B.U. fears return to Venezuela due to prior physical attack.

evidence.text: Before his detention by ICE, D.B.U. lived in Colorado with his wife, his eight‑year‑old child, and his baby.

evidence.text: R.M.M. has several tattoos for personal reasons, including one of his birth year; another of a family‑member’s name, and a tattoo of religious significance, but they have nothing to do with TdA.
